ygData.subject: Re: How would novelty search best be applied to a virtual creature controller
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Ken, when you mentioned that Tyler used no inputs but just internal pattern generation, it reminded me about a question I wanted to ask you a few days ago.

Hi Ken,

when you mentioned that Tyler used no inputs but just internal 
pa=
ttern generation, it reminded me about a question I wanted to ask 
you a fe=
w days ago. 

In novelty search, it searches for new behaviors, right. But =
are 
they "smart" in a sense.. For example, does the robot in the 2D maze 
=
experiment succeed just because of luck? It is possible that a 
behavior th=
at appears a solution to be discovered, but the robot acts 
like a beheaded=
 fly and reaches the solution by accident? How much 
this depends upon the =
environment and the inputs provided? Is it the 
same with fitness-based sea=
rch? I am asking this because I am about 
to introduce novelty search to ti=
me series forecasting which is very 
complex domain in terms of characteriz=
ing behavior. 

Peter

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <ksta=
nley@...> wrote:
>
> Peter C's message brings up another issue that might b=
e useful to
> Peter B:  For ambulation, it might be more effective to use l=
eaky
> integrator neurons than the usual feedforward neurons that are used =

in
> most ANN models.  The leaky integrators are better for precise 
timin=
g.
>  However, they may not be necessary if joint angles are being 
provide=
d
> as input.  But when joint angles are not provided, I do not think I
> h=
ave ever seen a regular recurrent ANN (i.e. non-leaky or not some
> other s=
pecial type of neuron) be able to make something walk.  In
> fact, the "fla=
iling" motions are often reduced significantly by 
leaky
> integrator neuro=
ns.  Tyler Streeter saw this when he worked on his
> biped with NEAT, which=
 actually stopped flailing after switching to
> leaky integrators.  However=
, in his project the network had no 
inputs
> and worked entirely through i=
nternal pattern generation.
> 
> ken
>

tanley" <kstanley@> 
wrote:
> > > >
> > > > Hi Peter, that's a good questio=
n and of course learning to 
> > control a 
> > > > virtual creature with n=
ovelty search is a complicated issue 
(and 
> > an 
> > > > appealing idea =
as well). 
> > > > 
> > > > First, you have to deal with all the representa=
tional and 
> > physical 
> > > > issues outside of novelty search, like ho=
w many inputs, how 
many 
> > > > outputs, and whether the body itself is n=
ot physically flawed 
in 
> > > > some way (which is possible).  As you are=
 experiencing, the 
> > > > inputs/outputs issue can be prohibitive even wi=
th feature 
> > > > selection.  It is also possible that HyperNEAT could be=
 
useful 
> > > > because it does not care about the # inputs or outputs (a=
nd 
can 
> > > > potentially exploit geometric regularities), but configuri=
ng 
the 
> > > > substrate then becomes the challenge.
> > > > 
> > > > Ass=
uming all of that stuff is set up well with whatever 
system, 
> > then 
> =
> > > novelty search is a potentially winning approach.  Yet as you 
> > po=
int 
> > > > out there are some big questions there as well.  In fact, we 
=
are 
> > > > currently trying to provide the best answers to these 
questio=
ns 
> > in 
> > > > ongoing research, but some general principles might hel=
p for 
now: 
> > > > 
> > > > First, the archive in novelty search does not=
 not need to 
contain 
> > > > every point ever visited.  Therefore, it ten=
ds to grow much 
> > slower 
> > > > than the #of evaluations.  However, if=
 it is indeed getting 
too 
> > big  
> > > > then it is not unreasonable t=
o collapse some of the archive 
> > points, 
> > > > although there is no s=
tandard method yet for how that should 
be 
> > > > done.  But we have reas=
on to believe there will be effective 
and 
> > > > simple ways to do that.=

> > > > 
> > > > Second, the issue of one individual looking different jus=
t 
> > because 
> > > > of a phase difference in effectivley the same behav=
ior is 
> > > > complicated.  For certain phase disaparities, the two 
indi=
viduals 
> > > > won't look all that different, but it is true that at some=
 
> > > > disparity, they may look very different.  Yet it is not clear 
> =
> > > whether that fact is actually problematic to the novelty 
search 
> >=
 or 
> > > > not, because it would simply reward both types of behavior.  
=
It 
> > is 
> > > > possible that the phase difference is a result of some =
useful 
> > > > genotypic change, which could make it a stepping stone to 
=
> > something 
> > > > better.  Or, it is possible that it is superfluous 
=
information 
> > and 
> > > > simply takes some extra time exploring the ar=
ea around the 
phase-
> > > > shifted individual.  So it is hard to say a p=
riori whether it 
is 
> > a 
> > > > major concern.  We will have better an=
swers to such questions 
as 
> > the 
> > > > technique is further explored=
.
> > > > 
> > > > However, I agree that it would be nice to be able to say=
 the 
two 
> > > > phase-shifted individuals are largely the same if that i=
s 
indeed 
> > > > what you want to say.  And for that, you would need a pa=
ttern-
> > > > matching metric to compute behavioral distance, i.e. 
someth=
ing 
> > more 
> > > > sophisiticated than simple Cartesian distance.  Ther=
e are 
> > certainly 
> > > > such metrics available.  However, it's import=
ant to recognize 
> > that 
> > > > it is not evident at this point that ig=
noring the phase shift 
is 
> > > > actually better than taking it into con=
sideration, because 
taking 
> > it 
> > > > into consideration just means =
adding more information to the 
> > novelty 
> > > > landscape.
> > > > 
> =
> > > So overall I think novelty search is a very promising 
direction 
> >=
 to 
> > > > go for such problems, but it is still in the realm of 
researc=
h 
> > (i.e. 
> > > > there is no existing precedent), so it will involve 
=
considerable 
> > > > trial and error to get it right until all these issue=
s are 
> > fleshed 
> > > > out more clearly.  Ultimately, though, if our h=
ypothesis 
about 
> > > > novelty vs. fitness is correct, novelty search ma=
y turn out 
to be 
> > > > the *only* way to get certain highly complex typ=
es of 
behavior to 
> > > > evolve in some domains, which is a sobering tho=
ught.  But if 
it 
> > is 
> > > > true, then there is not much to do other=
 than try it.
> > > > 
> > > > ken
